parts.label: (i)

content.text: Place the cup, with the base at the bottom, in square \(\mathbf{A}\) on this page. Draw carefully around the base of the cup. Remove the cup from the paper. Take measurements from your drawing to determine an accurate value for the diameter \(D_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the base of the cup

issues: table with too many empty cells

content.text: Square A

issues: table with too many empty cells

content.text: Place the cup, with the rim at the bottom, in square \(\mathbf{B}\) on this page. Draw carefully around the rim of the cup
Remove the cup from the paper. Take measurements from your drawing to determine the diameter \(D_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the rim of the cup
Square \(\mathbf{B}\)
Calculate the average diameter \(D\) of the cup using the equation \(D = \frac{D_{\mathrm{B}} + D_{\mathrm{T}}}{2}\)
Measure the vertical height \(h\) of the cup
1. Calculate the volume \(V\) of the cup using the equation \(V = 0.785 D^2 h\)
2. Calculate \(V / 2\)
Use the balance provided to measure the mass \(m\) of the cup containing the water
Determine the density \(\rho\) of water using the equation \(\rho = \frac{2m}{V}\)
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment. Include the unit
You are provided with water in beaker \(\mathbf{W}\)
Pour a volume \(V / 2\) of water into the measuring cylinder. Pour this water into the cup
A student carries out all the instructions for this experiment with care, but his value for the density of water \(\rho\) is not equal to the expected value
Suggest, with a reason, a part of the procedure, **(a)**, **(b)** or **(c)** that could give an unreliable result
part
reason
In this experiment, you will determine the density of water
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
You are provided with a plastic drinks cup
Use the thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker of hot water
• Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\). Immediately start the stopclock
• After \(30 \text{s}\), measure the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. Record the time \(t = 30 \text{s}\) and the temperature reading in the table
• Continue recording the time and temperature readings every 30 s until you have six sets of readings

Plot a graph of \(\theta /\mathrm{^\circ C}\) (y-axis) against \(t / \mathrm{s}\) (x-axis). You do **not** need to start the \(y\)-axis at the origin (0,0) but the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) must be marked on the \(y\)-axis
Draw a horizontal line across the graph grid to show the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) during the experiment.

A student plans to repeat the experiment using the same thermometer and the same volume of water. Suggest **two** changes to the apparatus or the procedure that would increase the rate of cooling of the water
State **one** precaution that you took in order to record accurate readings
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 2.1
Measure the distance \(\nu_{1}\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Calculate the focal length \(f_{1}\) of the lens using the equation \(f_{1} = \frac{u_{1} v_{1}}{(u_{1} + v_{1})}\)
Place the screen about \(100 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
• Place the lens between the object and the screen so that the centre of the lens is at a distance \(u_{1} = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the object
• Adjust the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
Repeat the procedure in (a), placing the lens between the object and the screen so that the centre of the lens is at a distance \(u_{2} = 30.0 \text{cm}\) from the object
Calculate the focal length \(f_{2}\) of the lens using the equation \(f_{2} = \frac{u_{2} v_{2}}{(u_{2} + v_{2})}\)
Calculate the average value of the focal length \(f\) of the lens, using the two results from parts (a) and (b). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
The student states that taking more measurements improves the reliability of the value obtained for \(f.\)
Suggest additional values for \(u\) that you would use
State two precautions that should be taken in this experiment to obtain accurate readings
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length \(f\) of a lens
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1
Fig. 3.1
A student is investigating whether the distance that a toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass
The following apparatus is available to the student:
a ramp
blocks to support the ramp as shown in Fig. 4.1
toy truck
a selection of masses
other standard apparatus from the physics laboratory
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the distance that the toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation
In your plan, you should:
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation
state any apparatus that you would use that is not included in the list above
state the key variables that you would control
draw a table, or tables, with column headings to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
You may add to the diagram in Fig. 4.1 to help your description
